question_details.query: Is using genetic modification to make crops unpalatable to primates an effective conservation strategy?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of using unpalatable buffer crops to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas on primate populations [1438]. A laboratory study found that pollen from genetically modified maize that produces a pesticide did not harm the survival or growth of eastern tiger swallowtail or spicebush swallowtail caterpillars when compared to non-genetically modified maize [3895].
summary_statements: There is no evidence for the effects of using unpalatable buffer crops to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas on primate populations.

A laboratory study found that pollen from genetically modified maize that produces a pesticide did not harm the survival or growth of eastern tiger swallowtail caterpillars when compared to non-genetically modified maize.

A laboratory study found that pollen from genetically modified maize that produces a pesticide did not harm the survival or growth of spicebush swallowtail caterpillars when compared to non-genetically modified maize.
